html.p: Why: Makes it look like you know what you are doing.
So What: Makes 'bad' field names easier to work with, or converts shorthand names to longer ones at the end of your SPL.
Be careful! You'd think rename wouldn't cause problems, but you can overwrite fields with null and cause other minor mayhem.

panel.html: We're using data we built earlier by using outputlookup. To build this see outputlookup | inputlookup mydata.csv While yours may differ slightly, that data for us is: "_time",salesperson,"Cars Sold This Hour" 1711665905,Rich,1 1711665905,David,1 1711662305,Rich,0 1711662305,David,0 1711658705,Rich,1 1711658705,David,2 1711655105,Rich,2 1711655105,David,3
You know, that field Cars Sold This Hour is hard to work with because of quoting and spaces and capital letters.
panel.title: Our original data

panel.html:
So we rename Cars Sold This Hour to carsperhour to work with. This is useful for fields with dots in them or {} brackets, too.
| rename "Cars Sold This Hour" AS carsperhour
panel.title: Renaming the awkward field

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | rename "Cars Sold This Hour" AS carsperhour

panel.html:
Normally though it's a command run near the end to make things pretty.
| rename "salesperson" AS "Sales Person"
panel.title: The "usual" way to do this

panel.html:
Also you can rename multiple fields at once, like
| rename salesperson AS "Sales Person" _time as Time
panel.title: Multiple renames

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | rename salesperson AS "Sales Person" _time as Time
